columns.text: In this problem, we are required to determine if agency problems are to be more or less likely severe in Germany and Japan than in the United States and the implications of large financial institutions becoming the dominant owners of stock in the United States for agency problems and corporate control.

Before we begin, let us first define agency problem.

**Agency problem** refers to the tendency of management to put its own needs at the expense of the shareholders.

Agency problems are likely to be less severe in Germany and Japan than in the United States due to a higher level institutional ownership. This means that in Germany and Japan, more companies' available stock are owned and managed by mutual or pension funds, insurance companies, or other large institutions.

Since large financial institutions such as mutual funds and pension funds have been becoming the dominant owners of stock in the United States, this may lead to a reduction in agency problems and a more efficient market for corporate operations and planning.

In this task, we are needed to provide our opinion on whether the issues that the agency will encounter in relation to the owner of the majority of shares in public enterprises will become less or more severe. In addition, the implications of this development for corporate control and regulatory agencies need to be analyzed.

In the context of corporate finance, the term **"agency problem"** often refers to a situation in which the interests of a company's management and those of the company's investors are in direct opposition to one another. Even though it is in the manager's best interest to maximize their personal wealth, they are obligated to make choices that will increase the wealth of the shareholders in their role as the agent for the shareholders, who are the principals.

We anticipate agency problems to be less severe in other nations, partly because of the comparatively low proportion of individual ownership. Fewer individual shareholders should limit the number of divergent perspectives about the organization's objectives. The large proportion of institutional ownership may result in more consensus between owners and management over choices regarding riskier ventures.

Because different people have different perspectives on how the company should be run and who should be in charge, agency issues will become more prevalent if there are an excessive number of individual investors who hold shares in the corporation. However, when the company is controlled by institutions, the agency problem will be mitigated since large organizations have more effective management and control mechanisms than individuals.

As a result, the severity of the agency problem will be reduced in nations such as Germany and Japan since institutions control the bulk of the shareholdings in companies in such nations. In recent years in the United States, huge financial institutions have become the predominant owners, which will eventually lead to decreased agency difficulties in the United States as well.

Large financial institutions, such as mutual funds and pension funds, will have fewer agency issues as a result of the analysts who get the idea of the businesses in which they invest. 

Such funds have a solid understanding of the financials. They will enhance corporate intervention and tighten the leash on managers, therefore reducing agency issues. In this way, managers will be able to do their best job for the company. Control of the corporation will be in their hands, and they will be able to designate individuals from the same field and expertise to the board, therefore working in the best interest of the firm and its shareholders.
